questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma present in Which CD4 count? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) <500

 

Kaposi's sarcoma is a common opportunistic infection associated with HIV infection. It typically presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells per cubic millimeter. Kaposi's sarcoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels. The exact CD4 count at which Kaposi's sarcoma presents can vary, but it is generally observed in patients with moderately suppressed immune systems, which corresponds to a CD4 count of less than 500 cells/mm³.

 

Graph showing the Opportunistic infections associated with HIV infections and correlation with CD4 T cells counts.

 

 

When the CD4 count is at 500, individuals might also face bacterial skin infections, HSV, and fungal infections. As the CD4 count drops further, other infections like hairy leukoplakia and tuberculosis (at CD4 < 400), PCP, Cryptococcus, and Toxoplasmosis (at CD4 < 200), and infections like MAC, CMV, and lymphoma (at CD4 < 50) can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients generally presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells/mm³.

questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis is experiencing three episodes of bleeding in stools per day but is otherwise stable. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-Aminosalicylic acid.

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, especially in a stable patient who is experiencing active symptoms like bleeding. It works as an anti-inflammatory agent in the colon and is effective in inducing and maintaining remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-Fluorouracil: This is a chemotherapeutic agent and is not used for treating ulcerative colitis. It's primarily used in cancer treatment.

 

Option C. Budesonide: While budesonide, a corticosteroid, is used in ulcerative colitis, it's generally reserved for more severe cases or when 5-ASA is ineffective. In a stable patient, it may not be the first choice.

 

Option D. 6-Mercaptopurine: This is an immunosuppressant used in ulcerative colitis primarily for maintenance therapy or in patients who haven't responded to other treatments, not typically as a first-line treatment in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis and is effective in reducing inflammation and maintaining remission in stable patients experiencing active symptoms.

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

 

Explanation:

 

The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.

 

Option B. 15 L/min: This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.

 

Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

 

The above lesion is most likely caused by  Sporothrix schencki (S. schenckii)

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. In its saprophytic stage or when cultured at 25°C, it assumes a filamentous form, composed of hyaline, septate hyphae 1 to 2 μm wide, with conidiogenous cells arising from undifferentiated hyphae forming conidia in groups on small, clustered denticles. These one-celled conidia are tear shaped to clavate and do not yield chains. The S. schenckii colonies never become cottony or floccose.

Infection with the dimorphic soil fungus S schenckii is usually transmitted by the mold form from organic matter through cutaneous inoculation. The mycosis has also been transmitted from animals through bites or scratches.

 

The initial reddish, necrotic, nodular papule of cutaneous sporotrichosis generally appears 1-10 weeks after a penetrating skin injury. The lesion is a suppurating granuloma that consists of histiocytes and giant cells, with neutrophils that accumulate in the center and that are surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

The fungal infection spreads from the initial lesion along lymphatic channels, forming the chain of indolent nodular and ulcerating lesions typical of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other tissues are involved by direct extension and, less often, by hematogenous dissemination. The most common extracutaneous infection sites are in the bones, joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae. Hematogenous dissemination—particularly in immunocompromised hosts—results in widely disseminated cutaneous and visceral infection, including meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen. It may cause pulmonary disease and local lymphadenitis, primarily in the submandibular and submaxillary regions. It is usually a benign, self-limited condition with no systemic symptoms except for mild neck pain.

 

Option C. Eumyectoma or mycetoma also called as Madura foot, is a chronic subcutaneous granulomatous soft-tissue infection. The etiological agent may be fungal (eumycetoma) or bacterial (actinomycetoma) and appears under microscopic examination as hyphae or thin filaments, respectively. The cardinal features of the disease are tumefaction, sinus formation, and presentation of grains or granules in draining exudate.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa is a common cause of chromoblastomycosis. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. The fungus is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, (known as sclerotic bodies) on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: Following a stab injury to the chest, the following imaging finding was noted. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

 

In this scenario, the patient has sustained a stab injury to the chest, and an X-ray has been provided as part of the diagnostic process. The X-ray described in the  reveals a white area on the affected side of the lung field.

Hemothorax: A hemothorax occurs when blood accumulates in the pleural cavity. On a chest X-ray, this condition presents as a white-out or opaque area on the affected side due to the fluid (blood) collecting in the pleural space. The clinical findings, such as hypotension (which can result from blood loss), further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: In contrast, a pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space, would show up on a chest X-ray as a black area (radiolucency) without lung markings, indicating air in the pleural space. This would not match the white-out appearance seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic Rupture: This condition would typically present with air-fluid levels within the chest cavity if abdominal organs have herniated into the thoracic cavity. However, this is not indicated by the described X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Lung Contusion: A lung contusion would appear as a focal area of consolidation (white patch) due to localized bleeding or bruising of the lung tissue, but it would not cause a widespread white-out of the lung field.

 

Thus, the presence of a white-out on the X-ray, along with clinical signs such as hypotension, suggests the correct diagnosis is hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

choices.text: Transfer objects from one hand to another

questions.text: Identify the milestone shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfer objects from one hand to another

 

The milestone shown in the image, where the child appears to be manipulating an object, is indicative of the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another. This skill typically develops around 6 months of age and is an important indicator of emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bidextrous approach: Refers to the ability to use both hands to pick an object, which typically develops by 4 months. This involves reaching for objects with both hands but does not necessarily involve the transfer of objects between hands.

 

Option C. Hand regard: This milestone, where an infant looks at and examines their own hand, typically occurs around 3 months of age. The image does not depict this behavior.

 

Option D. Hands come in midline: By around 4 months, infants begin to bring their hands together in the midline of their body. This is a precursor to more complex hand movements but is not what is shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

By around 6 months of age, infants typically develop the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another, demonstrating emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

questions.text: Which of the following is the method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leucodepleted blood

 

Explanation:

 

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are caused by antibodies in the recipient's plasma reacting with the donor's white blood cells (leukocytes) present in the transfused blood. The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the leukocytes, significantly reduces the risk of FNHTRs by eliminating the trigger for the antibody reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prophylactic paracetamol may help in managing fever if an FNHTR occurs, but it does not prevent the reaction itself.

 

Option B. Intravenous steroids are not typically used for the prevention of FNHTRs. Steroids may be administered in cases of severe transfusion reactions, but they do not specifically target the underlying cause of FNHTRs.

 

Option D. Saline-washed red cell transfusion is a method used to reduce the risk of allergic reactions due to the presence of plasma proteins, but it does not directly address the issue of FNHTRs caused by leukocyte antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the donor's white blood cells, is the recommended method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions caused by antibody reactions against the transfused leukocytes.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine didelphys: Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever

 

 

Option C. Bicornuate uterus: Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)

 

 

Option D. Unicornuate uterus: Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.

 

Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

choices.text: Dark ground microscopy

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

 

MHC Class II molecules are specifically involved in presenting exogenous antigens, ( antigens foreign to the body eg antigens of bacteria, viruses etc)  not endogenous ( self-antigens). These exogenous antigens are typically derived from organisms outside the cell, such as bacteria or viruses that have been ingested by the cell via phagocytosis or endocytosis. MHC Class II then presents peptides from these processed antigens to CD4+ T cells, triggering an immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells: True, which is a key component of the immune response modulation.

 

Option B. The action of MHC II occurs via the endocytic pathway: True, this pathway involves the processing of phagocytosed material.

 

Option D. MHC II is present on antigen-presenting cells: True, which is essential for initiating the immune response by interacting with CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM


Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) is a congenital lung lesion characterized by multiple cystic spaces within the lungs, often detected through imaging such as CT or X-rays. In this case, the child’s imaging shows a multi-cystic, bubbly appearance with air-filled spaces, which is typical of CPAM. CPAM often presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to the abnormal lung structure. Although the images combine antenatal ultrasound and postnatal imaging, they highlight the congenital nature of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This condition involves pus and air within the pleural cavity, usually caused by infection or trauma. It presents with an air-fluid level, often with signs of pleural infection such as fever and chest pain. The multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging does not match this condition.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH involves the herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, usually on the left side. CDH presents with bowel loops in the chest and displacement of the lung tissue, which is not observed here. The appearance of the lesion on the right side with multiple air-filled cysts rules out CDH.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is a localized area of necrosis and pus within the lung, often appearing as a round lesion with an air-fluid level. This differs significantly from the bubbly, multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


CPAM is characterized by multiple cystic, air-filled spaces in the lung and is a congenital lesion that often presents with recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Correctly identified based on the image, this stricture is located in the bulbar region of the urethra, just below the prostate and above the penile segment.

 

This is a urethrogram, a type of radiographic study used to evaluate the urethra. The narrowing seen in the image is consistent with a bulbar urethral stricture, which typically occurs in the part of the urethra that runs through the bulb of the penis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prostatomegaly: This would show an enlarged prostate, which typically does not affect the urethra directly on a urethrogram unless there is significant compression or involvement of the prostatic urethra.

 

Option B. Membranous urethral stricture: This type of stricture would occur in the membranous segment of the urethra, which is located between the prostate and the bulbous urethra. The location in this image does not correspond to that segment.

 

Option D. Normal urethra: This would show an unobstructed and uniformly calibred urethral passage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Urethral strictures, particularly in the bulbar region, are commonly evaluated and diagnosed with a urethrogram, which provides clear visualization of any narrowing or obstruction along the urethral tract.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, and its deficiency can lead to a bleeding tendency. Bulky stools that stick to the pan can be indicative of malabsorption issues, which could result in inadequate absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin K. This deficiency can lead to bleeding problems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bleeding disorders but can lead to other health issues, including vision problems.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in various symptoms, but it is not known to directly cause bleeding disorders.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency may lead to neurological and muscle problems but is not a common cause of bleeding disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 532

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency by the family members. His CT scan was done which showed the following image. Which of the following can be given to this patient in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin K

 

The CT scan image shows a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is a type of intracranial hemorrhage characterized by a crescent-shaped bleed along the brain's surface, often resulting from head trauma. In the case of traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, the primary concern is to stop the bleeding and manage intracranial pressure.

 

Vitamin K is an essential factor in the clotting cascade and is used to promote clotting and reduce bleeding. It is especially useful if the patient is suspected to be on anticoagulant therapy, as it helps counteract the effects of such medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots in ischemic stroke or myocardial infarction. Administering it in the context of a hemorrhagic stroke would worsen the bleeding.

 

Option B. Retiplase: Similar to alteplase, retiplase is another thrombolytic agent and is contraindicated in cases of hemorrhage due to its potential to exacerbate bleeding.

 

Option D. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents clot formation. Giving heparin in a situation of intracranial hemorrhage would further inhibit clotting and worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, such as a subdural hematoma, Vitamin K is administered to promote blood clotting and reduce further bleeding, especially if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found maximum in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Animal products

 

Vitamin B12 is most abundant in animal-derived foods such as meat, fish, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. These sources are rich in this essential vitamin, making it an important part of the diets of individuals who consume animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green Leafy Vegetables: Green leafy vegetables, while nutritious and a source of many vitamins and minerals, are generally not a significant source of vitamin B12. In fact, plant-based sources of B12 are limited, and green leafy vegetables are not a reliable source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Roots and Tubers: Roots and tubers are also not a substantial source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not typically found in plant-based foods in significant quantities, so relying solely on roots and tubers for B12 would likely result in a deficiency.

 

Option D. Sunlight: Sunlight is not a source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not synthesized by the body through exposure to sunlight, as is the case with vitamin D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 is naturally present in foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. Hence, vegetarians usually are prone to develop vitamin b12 deficiency. Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Marked structure is connected to which part of basal nuclei (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpus striatum

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the substantia nigra, identified by its pigmented appearance. The substantia nigra is a crucial component of the basal nuclei, involved in the regulation of movement.

 

The substantia nigra communicates with the basal nuclei through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is composed of dopaminergic neurons connecting the substantia nigra to the corpus striatum. This pathway plays a significant role in the modulation of motor activities and is notably affected in Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: Incorrect because the thalamus primarily acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and does not directly connect with the substantia nigra in the context of the basal nuclei.

 

Option B. Subthalamic nucleus: Incorrect because while it is a component of the basal nuclei, it is not the primary structure connected to the substantia nigra in the context of the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option C. Globus pallidum: Incorrect because the globus pallidum is involved in regulating voluntary movement but does not have the direct nigrostriatal connection as the corpus striatum does with the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra is connected to the corpus striatum through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is essential for motor control.

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: What is true about this position? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sniffing position for intubation

 

The image illustrates the "sniffing position," which is the ideal position for tracheal intubation. In this position, the patient’s head is elevated and extended at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes. This alignment facilitates a direct line of sight during laryngoscopy, making intubation easier. The sniffing position is a standard recommendation for intubating patients under general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideal position for Bougie insertion: The sniffing position is primarily recognized for its role in enhancing the view during direct laryngoscopy.

 

Option C. Ideal position for Neurosurgery: This option is incorrect because the sniffing position is not typically used for neurosurgical procedures. Neurosurgery often requires specific head and neck positioning to optimize access to the brain or spine, which differs from the sniffing position.

 

Option D. Neck position for intubation: The term "neck position for intubation" is too vague. The correct terminology for the position depicted in the image is the "sniffing position," which specifically describes the head and neck alignment optimal for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sniffing position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it the ideal position for tracheal intubation

questions.text: A dead body shows the following finding as in the image. What is the case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Smothering

 

The image shows signs consistent with smothering, a form of asphyxiation where the airflow is blocked by an external force, usually involving the face or mouth, preventing the person from breathing. In smothering, injuries are typically seen on the face rather than the neck. There may be signs of trauma around the mouth and nose, indicating forceful application, such as abrasions or bruising, which is evident in the provided image. This physical evidence strongly points to smothering as the cause of death, where force is applied directly to the face, blocking the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: Hanging involves the compression of the neck due to the body’s weight pulling down on a ligature around the neck, leading to strangulation and neck injuries. The primary injury site is the neck, not the face, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Gagging: Gagging involves inserting a foreign object into the mouth, typically to prevent the person from making noise rather than to kill. Although accidental asphyxia can occur if the object obstructs the airway deeply, injuries are usually minimal and not the result of direct trauma like in smothering. Gagging does not cause the kind of facial trauma visible in the image.

 

Option C. Garrotting: Garrotting is a form of strangulation where the neck is compressed with a ligature and twisted with a lever, leading to neck injuries. This method results in visible trauma around the neck, not the face. Since the injuries shown are facial, garrotting is not the Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smothering is characterized by facial injuries resulting from forceful application that obstructs breathing, distinguishing it from neck compression injuries seen in hanging or garrotting.

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is scheduled to receive a kidney transplant from his son who is a compatible donor. What is this type of transplant known as?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Allograft

 

Explanation:

 

An allograft is a transplantation of tissue or an organ from one individual to another of the same species but with different genetic makeup. In this scenario, the kidney transplant from a son to his father is an example of an allograft because they are both human but genetically different individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autograft: An autograft is a transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. Examples include skin grafts taken from one area of the body to treat burns in another area.

 

Option C. Xenograft: A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs from one species to another. This type of transplant is not common in clinical practice due to the high risk of immune rejection and other complications. An example would be a pig heart valve transplanted into a human.

 

Option D. Isograft: An isograft is a transplantation of tissue or organs between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of transplant is also known as a syngeneic transplant and has the advantage of minimal risk of immune rejection due to the genetic identity between the donor and the recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A kidney transplant from a son to his father is classified as an allograft because it involves the transfer of an organ between two genetically different individuals of the same species.

choices.text: Most commonly seen in adolescent male

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding in ENT emergency. On physical examination: Patient seems pale having Hb: 9 gm/dl. On CECT: a mass is seen which pushes septum to the contralateral side & anterior bowing of maxillary antrum is seen. All of the given statements are true regarding this mass except?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Best treated by radiation

 

Explanation

 

The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding, pallor, and a mass pushing the septum to the contralateral side with anterior bowing of the maxillary antrum (Colman-Miller sign), are indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is most commonly seen in adolescent males, can spread to the orbit and intracranially, but it is not best treated by radiation. The primary treatment for JNA is surgical resection, not radiation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male: This is correct. JNA predominantly affects adolescent males.

 

Option B. Can spread to orbit: This is correct. JNA can extend into the orbit due to its aggressive nature.

 

Option D. Can spread intracranially: This is correct. JNA can invade the cranial cavity, leading to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a condition that is most commonly seen in adolescent males and primarily treated with surgical resection, not radiation.

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.

 

Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

 

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons). The basic cycles of transmission are:

 

(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

 

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Caused by Plasmodium parasites, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily involves a human-mosquito-human cycle without bird involvement.

 

Option C. Plague: Caused by Yersinia pestis, typically involves rodents and fleas in its transmission cycle; humans are incidental hosts.

 

Option D. Paragonimiasis: Caused by Paragonimus worms, involves a cycle between snails, crabs/crayfish, and mammals (including humans), but not birds or typical arthropods like mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-hydroxytryptamine

 

  • Serotonin is 5-hydroxytryptamine. It is produced in the brain, mast cells, platelets and gastrointestinal tract mucosa.
  • Tryptophan is first hydroxylated by tryptophan hydroxylase. The co-enzyme is tetrahydrobiopterin. The tetrahydrobiopterin is regenerated using NADPH.
  • In the next step, 5-hydroxytryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxytryptamine (5HT), (serotonin). The enzyme, decarboxylase requires pyridoxal phosphate.
  • The effect of serotonin is dependent on the amount of serotonin available at the synaptic site. Part of the serotonin released is again taken up (reuptake). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) are widely used in the treatment of psychiatric disorders
  • Monoamine oxidase (MAO) converts serotonin to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (HIAA). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having an amino group attached to a carbon atom. MAO inhibitors (e.g., iproniazid) will cause mood elevation.

 

Clinical correlation:

 

CARCINOID SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-hydroxytryptophan: This is a precursor to serotonin, involved in its biosynthetic pathway, but not the same as serotonin.

 

Option C. 5-carboxytryptamine: This compound does not exist in serotonin’s metabolic pathway and is unrelated to its structure or function.

 

Option D. 5-carboxytryptophan: This is also not part of the serotonin synthesis or its structure; it is a hypothetical derivative that does not have a role in serotonin’s biological actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a crucial neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan and involved in numerous physiological processes. Its synthesis involves specific enzymatic actions that are targeted pharmacologically to manage various psychiatric

choices.text: Measure CA 125 levels
Follow up after 6 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

 

A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and size less than 8 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to follow up after 6-12 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Functional Ovarian Cyst: In reproductive-aged women, a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm is likely functional.
  • Follow-Up: The recommended management is to follow up after 6-12 weeks with a repeat ultrasound to check if the cyst resolves on its own.
  • Indications for Further Intervention: Surgical treatment is warranted if there are worrying features, the cyst is greater than 8 cm, there are significant symptoms, or CA-125 levels are raised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA 125 levels: CA 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and is more relevant in postmenopausal women. It has limited role in premenopausal women with clear, simple cysts.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: Surgical intervention such as laparoscopy is not immediately necessary for a 5 cm cyst unless there are concerning features or persistence after follow-up.

 

Option D. CT pelvis: CT scan is not typically indicated for initial assessment of a simple ovarian cyst detected on ultrasound.

 

Additional information:

 

  • OC Pills: Oral contraceptive pills have not been proven effective in treating simple ovarian cysts, though they are often used.
  • Simple Ovarian Cysts: Any simple ovarian cyst less than 5 cm without symptoms can be left alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.

 

Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg217

questions.text: In the adjacent graph phase Ib represents which one of the following property? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plasticity

 

Correct. Plasticity refers to the ability of the bladder to accommodate increasing volumes of urine with little to no increase in intravesical pressure. The plateau phase (Ib) where the pressure remains relatively stable despite increasing volume is indicative of the bladder's plasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elasticity: Incorrect. Elasticity refers to the ability of a material or tissue to resume its normal shape after being stretched or compressed. In the context of bladder physiology, the initial part of the curve would represent elasticity as the bladder wall stretches without a significant increase in pressure.

 

Option C. Contractility: Incorrect. Contractility refers to the ability of the bladder muscle (detrusor muscle) to contract. This would be assessed during the voiding phase of the cystometrogram, not during the filling phase which is depicted in the graph.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. One of the properties listed (Plasticity) does describe phase Ib of the graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase Ib in the bladder pressure-volume graph represents the property of plasticity, where the bladder accommodates increasing urine volume with minimal increase in intravesical pressure.

questions.text: A farmer had a lesion on his shoulder. Histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

The histopathological image provided shows features consistent with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). The key characteristics that support this diagnosis are the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

 

Keratin pearls are concentric, whorl-like structures composed of keratinized cells, which are a hallmark of well-differentiated SCC. The presence of keratin indicates that the tumor cells are undergoing a process of keratinization, which is a characteristic feature of squamous epithelium. In the image, the pink, circular structures with a laminated appearance are keratin pearls.

 

Intercellular bridges, also known as desmosomes, are specialized cell junctions that connect adjacent squamous epithelial cells. These bridges help maintain the structural integrity of the epithelium and are visible as small, spiky projections between the tumor cells in the image.

 

The occupation of the patient (farmer) is also relevant, as prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight is a major risk factor for the development of SCC, particularly on sun-exposed areas like the shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is another type of skin cancer that arises from the basal layer of the epidermis. However, BCC typically lacks keratinization and the formation of keratin pearls, which are seen in this image.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus. Histologically, it is characterized by the presence of molluscum bodies, which are large, eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions within the keratinocytes. These features are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Verrucous carcinoma: Verrucous carcinoma is a rare, low-grade variant of SCC that typically presents as a warty, exophytic growth. While it may show some keratinization, the classic keratin pearls and intercellular bridges seen in this image are more suggestive of conventional SCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges in a skin biopsy is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma, particularly in a patient with a history of prolonged sun exposure.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: The recommended free/residual chlorine level in the water after chlorination of a well is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5 ppm after 1 hour

 

The primary purpose of chlorination is to disinfect water and ensure that it is safe for consumption. After chlorination, it is important to have a certain level of free or residual chlorine in the water to maintain its safety as it passes through the distribution system. The residual chlorine provides ongoing disinfection to prevent contamination after the initial chlorination.

 

For well water, the recommended free or residual chlorine level should be 0.5 ppm (parts per million) after a contact period of 1 hour. This level is sufficient to kill most pathogens in the water and ensure it remains safe for consumption.

 

Maintaining this chlorine level is crucial as it indicates that the water has been effectively disinfected and is less likely to harbor harmful microorganisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Minimum Chlorine Levels:
    • Drinking Water: The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm).
    • Swimming Pools: A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness.
    • Killing Cyclopes: To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • Chloroscope device is used to measure chlorine levels in water, ensuring to meet the health and safety standards.
  • Orthotolidine Test is utilized for measuring the chlorine content in water, confirming whether the necessary disinfection levels are being maintained.
  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water, which helps determine how much bleaching powder should be added to achieve effective disinfection.
  • The main disinfecting agent in chlorine treatments is hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is effective in neutralizing pathogens and ensuring water safety.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. She is prescribed metronidazole as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following should she avoid consuming while on this medication? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol

 

  • Patients taking metronidazole are advised to avoid alcohol consumption. Metronidazole and alcohol can interact to cause a disulfiram-like reaction, leading to symptoms such as flushing, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and even more severe reactions in some cases. This interaction can occur not only with oral alcohol consumption but also with alcohol contained in mouthwashes and certain medications.
  • Disulfiram is an aversive drug, that inhibits the aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body, which can lead to symptoms like throbbing headache, flushing, chest tightness, visual disturbances, nausea etc. Hence these symptoms prevent the patient from taking alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grapefruit juice: There is no known significant interaction between grapefruit juice and metronidazole.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepine: While caution may be advised when combining any medications that can have CNS effects, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between benzodiazepines and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Option D. SSRI: Similar to benzodiazepines, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between SSRIs and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs that can cause disulfiram like reaction include:

 

Cyclic:  Cefoperazone, Chlorpropamide

 

G:         Grieseofulvin

 

M:        Metronidazole

 

P:         Procarbazine
